text: Analysing the data is quite complicated (there is also a lockdown in effect, so not easy to see impact of vaccination only), but there might be encouraging numbers from Israel: <https://twitter.com/segal_eran/status/1356313705684869121|https://twitter.com/segal_eran/status/1356313705684869121>

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/segal_eran|@segal_eran>: Israel: We say with caution, the magic has started

Note blue lines, of 60+ years old (first to vaccinate), in the past 2 weeks:

~35% drop in cases
~30% drop in hospitalizations
~20% drop in critically ill

Stronger than in younger people & not seen in previous lockdown

>>> <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EtKUPKJXMAYoVkL.jpg>
attachments.text:

text:
that is a really hard confounding factor.
because they hit 70% vaccinations for the over 60 group at the same time lockdown started.

Lockdown and vaccinations are both expected to take 2 weeks to kick in.

text: what he notes in the reply to this tweet is that the drop of cases in 60+ wasn't seen in previous lockdowns.  but yeah, not easy to discriminate between the two effects

attachments.title: Covid: Israel's vaccine rollout linked to infection fall
attachments.text: Less than 0.1% of vaccinated people caught coronavirus, and far fewer became ill.
attachments.fallback: BBC News: Covid: Israel's vaccine rollout linked to infection fall

text: Yeah but I guess they’ll combine locdowns with vaccine most places. If the vaccine achieves herd immunity that just means that R will be less than 1. But with a high enough number of infecteds, an R of say 0.9 would still burn through a massive part of the population before the disease is gone
